review.title: Inference rules for RDF(S) and OWL in N3Logic
review.abstract: This paper presents inference rules for Resource Description Framework (RDF), RDF Schema (RDFS) and Web Ontology Language (OWL). Our formalization is based on Notation 3 Logic, which extended RDF by logical symbols and created Semantic Web logic for deductive RDF graph stores. We also propose OWL-P that is a lightweight formalism of OWL and supports soft inferences by omitting complex language constructs.

sections.text: I. INTRODUCTIONResource Description Framework (RDF) is a general method for conceptual description or modeling of information implemented in web resources. RDF schema (RDFS) expands RDF to include classes that provide basic elements for describing vocabulary. OWL adds more vocabulary to describe properties and classes, i.e. relationships between classes, cardinality, and richer typing of properties. Unfortunately, OWL has a high worst-case complexity for key-conclusion problems. To solve this problem, we propose a lightweight OWL profile called the OWL-P.A rule, which is perhaps one of the most comprehensible concepts in computer science. It consists of the condition and the conclusion. If a condition that is verifiable in some data sets is processed, then the conclusion.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This paper defines how knowledge and logic can be used in the semantic web environment. We present inference rules RDF, RDF schema and OWL. All rules are tested in argumentation machines. Our formalization is based on Notation 3 Logic, which extended RDF with logical symbols and created a new semantic web logic. In addition, we propose a lightweight OWL profile called OWL-P. Our proposed rule will be useful for deductive RDF graph stores.
